_exec_summary.SummaryText:
LENROC   COMPANY:     Risk  Management  Plan     May 15, 2004
Plant  Facility:   16051  Railroad St. NW,   Ephrata,  Washington  98823


                                EXECUTIVE   SUMMARY

1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

In this manufacturing facility, we handle  Ammonium Hydroxide  (Aqua Ammonia above 20% by weight analysis of  Ammonia)  which is considered hazardous by EPA.  This product is a well-known nitrogen fertilizer which is used through out Eastern Washington.  The management and employees of Lenroc Company who operate the plant facility are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of Ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Ephrata Fire Department,  Grant County Emergency Services, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2.  Facility Information

    *  The primary activity at the facility is the production of a cattle feed supplement. Aqua  Ammonia is co-produced during  this production and is used as a nitrogen fertilizer.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.
   *   The  regulated substance handled at this facility  is  Ammonia (20% or higher in water solution)
   *   The maximum quantity stored at the facility  would be  500,000 gallons  of   23.0% Aqua  Ammonia in 
         two tanks  (300,000 gallons each tank)  during the period  March 1  to  July 1  each year.



3.  The general accidental release prevention program

This facility complies with  EPA's  Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  Employees are trained in the safe storage and handling of Aqua  Ammonia.

4.  The Five-year  accident  history

There have been no accidental releases of Aqua Ammonia in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries, property damage, eva

cuations, or environmental damage at the facility or offsite. 

5.  The emergency response program.

     The facility has
     *  a written emergency action plan and spill response plan in accordance with Washington State Code.

    *  provided state and local authorities emergency planning and community right-to-know information as 
        required under SARA  Title  III  (EPCRA).

    *  a written emergency response program in accordance with Washington State Code , including
         pre-emergency planning and employee training.

   *  conducted facility tours involving the  Ephrata Fire Department and Grant County Emergency Services

6.  Planned changes to improve safety

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific Aqua  Ammonia  safety recommendations at this time.
